question: What is the primary function of astrocytes in the central nervous system?
answers: Regulate blood-brain barrier and ion balance
short_explanation: Astrocytes help regulate the blood-brain barrier and maintain extracellular ion balance.
long_explanation: Astrocytes are star-shaped glial cells that support neurons by maintaining the extracellular environment, repairing the CNS after injury, and regulating the blood-brain barrier.
applied_example: Understanding astrocyte function helps massage therapists appreciate how neurological inflammation can affect muscle tone and client sensation.
text: What is the primary function of astrocytes in the central nervous system?
options: Regulate blood-brain barrier and ion balance
correctAnswer: Regulate blood-brain barrier and ion balance
abcd: C. Regulate blood-brain barrier and ion balance

question: Which type of glial cell forms the myelin sheath in the central nervous system?
short_explanation: Oligodendrocytes myelinate axons in the CNS.
long_explanation: Each oligodendrocyte can extend its processes to multiple axons, forming segments of myelin that increase the speed of electrical conduction.
applied_example: Damage to oligodendrocytes is seen in MS, which may present as sensory dysfunction during bodywork assessments.
text: Which type of glial cell forms the myelin sheath in the central nervous system?

question: What is the role of microglia in the nervous system?
short_explanation: Microglia serve as immune cells within the CNS.
long_explanation: Microglia constantly survey the CNS and respond to injury or infection by phagocytosing debris and releasing inflammatory cytokines.
applied_example: Overactivation of microglia may contribute to chronic pain, relevant in neuropathic massage adaptations.
text: What is the role of microglia in the nervous system?
abcd: C. Act as immune defense cells

question: Which glial cells line the ventricles of the brain and produce cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)?
short_explanation: Ependymal cells produce and circulate cerebrospinal fluid.
long_explanation: Ependymal cells form a barrier between CSF and neural tissue and aid in fluid movement through cilia. They are essential to CNS homeostasis.
applied_example: Clients with hydrocephalus may present with symptoms requiring modified head or neck massage protocols.
text: Which glial cells line the ventricles of the brain and produce cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)?

question: Which glial cells are found in the peripheral nervous system and provide myelin?
short_explanation: Schwann cells myelinate axons in the PNS.
long_explanation: Each Schwann cell wraps around a portion of one axon to form a myelin sheath, enhancing electrical signal speed in peripheral nerves.
applied_example: Massage near nerve entrapments (e.g. carpal tunnel) may be informed by Schwann cell health.
text: Which glial cells are found in the peripheral nervous system and provide myelin?

question: Which glial cells participate in synaptic pruning and neurotransmitter uptake?
short_explanation: Astrocytes regulate neurotransmitters and remove excess synaptic debris.
long_explanation: Astrocytes help modulate synaptic activity by recycling neurotransmitters like glutamate and GABA, contributing to synaptic plasticity and neural homeostasis.
applied_example: Understanding astrocytic function is relevant in chronic stress or PTSD, often presenting with altered nervous system tone during massage.
text: Which glial cells participate in synaptic pruning and neurotransmitter uptake?

question: Which glial cells are most involved in the formation of the glial scar after injury?
short_explanation: Astrocytes form glial scars after CNS injury.
long_explanation: After trauma or inflammation, astrocytes proliferate and form dense scars to wall off injury, limiting regeneration but protecting healthy tissue.
applied_example: In clients with spinal cord injury, glial scar formation affects neurological recovery and massage sensitivity.
text: Which glial cells are most involved in the formation of the glial scar after injury?

question: Which glial cell type maintains the ionic environment around neurons?
short_explanation: Astrocytes help buffer potassium ions around neurons.
long_explanation: Astrocytes absorb extracellular potassium ions released during neuronal activity, preventing hyperexcitability and maintaining signaling balance.
applied_example: Proper ionic balance supports smooth neuromuscular function, relevant for massage therapy targeting spasms or tremors.
source_reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology
text: Which glial cell type maintains the ionic environment around neurons?

question: Which glial cell is primarily responsible for removing cellular debris after CNS injury?
short_explanation: Microglia clean up cellular debris post-injury.
long_explanation: As CNS-resident macrophages, microglia rapidly respond to neuronal damage by engulfing apoptotic cells and releasing growth factors or inflammatory mediators.
applied_example: Massage adaptations for neuroinflammatory conditions benefit from understanding microglial behavior.
text: Which glial cell is primarily responsible for removing cellular debris after CNS injury?

question: Which glial cell has a role in guiding developing neurons during embryogenesis?
short_explanation: Radial glial cells act as scaffolding for developing neurons.
long_explanation: During embryonic development, radial glia guide migrating neurons to their final locations and later differentiate into other glial types.
applied_example: Understanding developmental pathways helps therapists contextualize congenital conditions affecting movement or coordination.
text: Which glial cell has a role in guiding developing neurons during embryogenesis?
